semantic_identifier: 9050851 - Lanternvale Properties - sales_pitch - Discussion with Tyler Wheeler

hierarchy.meeting_title: 9050851 - Lanternvale Properties - sales_pitch - Discussion with Tyler Wheeler

sections.text: James Choi: Hi Tyler, James Choi here. Thanks for taking a few minutes—did I catch you at an okay time?
Tyler Wheeler: Hey James. I’ve got a few minutes, but I’m between things. What’s up?

James Choi: Totally get it—I’ll keep it tight. I’m calling because we work with revenue teams that live in Salesforce or HubSpot and are trying to get more consistent deal follow-through and forecasting without adding another system. Our product is called Sales_Accelerator, and it sits on top of your CRM to recommend the best next action on each opportunity and alert you when deals are at risk.
Tyler Wheeler: We already have Salesforce and some dashboards. I’m not really looking to add more tools right now.

James Choi: That makes sense. The quick distinction is: dashboards tell you what happened; Sales_Accelerator tells reps what to do next—right inside the CRM. One feature that tends to resonate is our sales follow-up recommendations. For example, if a meeting happened but there’s no follow-up logged, it will prompt a recap email plus concrete next steps, and it’ll nudge the rep to put dates on a mutual action plan so deals don’t drift.
Tyler Wheeler: Okay. But we’ve tried “next best action” stuff before. It ends up being noise, and reps ignore it.

James Choi: Fair pushback. We’ve seen that too when recommendations are generic. Our approach is more contextual: it looks at the opportunity stage, stakeholder coverage—like whether you’re single-threaded—mutual plan completeness, and recent activity. If it sees only one contact engaged late in the cycle, it’ll recommend multi-threading and suggest a simple task queue, like “add procurement,” “loop in security,” “schedule exec alignment,” based on what usually prevents stalls.
Tyler Wheeler: That sounds like more process. Our reps don’t want another checklist.

James Choi: They shouldn’t have to adopt a heavy methodology. This is lightweight—think “here are the two actions most likely to move this deal forward” rather than “fill out 20 fields.” And sales ops can use it too. One use case we see a lot: sales ops identifies pipeline bottlenecks by stage-to-stage conversion, segmented by rep or segment, and then the system recommends process fixes—like introducing a security review step earlier—then monitors whether conversion improves.
Tyler Wheeler: We’re not a huge sales org. We’re a property group—our pipeline is… it’s not SaaS.

James Choi: Understood. Even outside SaaS, teams still deal with deal slippage—late follow-ups, single-threading, stalled steps, missed handoffs. If you have opportunities with stages, contacts, and activities in Salesforce, the recommendations still apply. Quick question: do you have a consistent issue where deals sit in a stage longer than expected?
Tyler Wheeler: Honestly, our bigger issue is lead quality and timing. And we’re in the middle of a CRM cleanup. So we’re not in a place to layer anything on.

James Choi: If data hygiene is in motion, that’s a real constraint. Sales_Accelerator depends on activity and stage data to be meaningful. That said, it can sometimes help highlight where the process breaks—like if reps aren’t logging meetings or next steps—and give you visibility into those gaps. But I don’t want to force-fit it if you’re prioritizing cleanup.
Tyler Wheeler: Yeah, and we also just rolled out a new workflow in Salesforce. My team is already complaining about change fatigue.

James Choi: I hear you. Let me keep this to what might be worth a follow-up: the follow-up recommendations are designed to reduce rep effort, not increase it—like generating a recap-and-next-steps prompt when a meeting occurred without a follow-up, or reminding them to lock mutual next steps. But if adoption is the concern, it’s probably not the right timing unless there’s a specific pain—like forecasting accuracy or deals slipping late.
Tyler Wheeler: Forecasting is always hard, but we’re not going to buy something for that this quarter. Budget is tight.

James Choi: Got it—so not a near-term budget window. Would a short, later conversation still be useful, purely to see whether it could fit after your cleanup? I’m thinking a 20-minute discovery with you or whoever owns sales ops, just to map your stages and see if the bottlenecks use case even applies.
Tyler Wheeler: I don’t think so. We’ve got too much going on, and I don’t want to pull in sales ops for another vendor overview.

James Choi: Fair. Last thing I want is to be another distraction. If I send a one-pager summarizing the follow-up recommendations and the pipeline bottleneck view—just so you have it on file—would that be okay?
Tyler Wheeler: You can email it, sure. But I can’t promise I’ll look at it soon.
James Choi: That’s completely fine. What’s the best email for you?
Tyler Wheeler: tyler.wheeler@lanternvale.com.
James Choi: Perfect—thank you. And just so I’m respectful on follow-ups: when would it make sense for me to check back in—after the CRM cleanup, maybe Q2?
Tyler Wheeler: Yeah, maybe Q2. But again, no guarantees.

James Choi: Understood. I’ll send the one-pager today and set a reminder to reach out in early Q2. If anything changes—like if you start seeing deals stalling because follow-ups aren’t happening—reply to that email and we can take a fresh look.
Tyler Wheeler: Sounds good. I’ve got to jump.
James Choi: Thanks Tyler—appreciate your time. Talk soon.
